mcqs.question: The pinhole camera model assumes that a 3D world point \((X, Y, Z)\) projects to an image point \((x, y)\) through perspective projection. Under the standard pinhole model with the camera center at the origin and image plane at \(Z = f\), the correct projection equations are:
mcqs.learning_objective: Recall the basic perspective projection equations of the pinhole camera model.

mcqs.question: In homogeneous coordinates, the full 3×4 camera projection matrix \(P\) for a pinhole camera with intrinsic matrix \(K\) and extrinsic parameters \([R \; t]\) is given by:
mcqs.learning_objective: Derive the general form of the camera projection matrix in homogeneous coordinates.

mcqs.question: The intrinsic parameter \(\alpha_x = f \cdot m_x\) represents:

options.B: The focal length in horizontal pixel units
options.C: The principal point offset in y-direction

mcqs.learning_objective: Interpret the components of the intrinsic calibration matrix \(K\).

mcqs.question: A finite camera has exactly how many degrees of freedom in its projection matrix \(P\)?
mcqs.learning_objective: Understand the dimensionality of general projective cameras.

mcqs.question: Radial distortion in real lenses causes straight lines in the world to appear curved in the image. The distortion model commonly used corrects coordinates \((x_d, y_d)\) to undistorted \((x_u, y_u)\) via:
mcqs.learning_objective: Recall the polynomial radial distortion model and its direction of correction.

mcqs.question: The principal point \((c_x, c_y)\) is defined as:

options.A: The center of the sensor array
options.B: The optical axis intersection with the image plane
options.D: The vanishing point of parallel lines

mcqs.learning_objective: Define the role of the principal point in camera calibration.

mcqs.question: In the pinhole model, a point at infinity in 3D (direction vector) projects to:

options.B: A vanishing point in the image

mcqs.learning_objective: Explain the imaging of points at infinity and vanishing points.

mcqs.question: Camera calibration using a known 3D calibration object (e.g., checkerboard) typically solves for:

options.C: Both intrinsic \(K\) and per-view extrinsics \(R, t\)

mcqs.learning_objective: Describe the standard camera calibration pipeline.

mcqs.question: The skew parameter \(s\) in the intrinsic matrix is zero when:
mcqs.learning_objective: Interpret the skew parameter in modern digital cameras.

mcqs.question: The weak perspective (scaled orthographic) approximation is valid when:

options.A: Scene depth variation is small compared to average distance to camera

mcqs.learning_objective: Recognize conditions under which perspective effects can be approximated linearly.

essay.prompt: Provide a comprehensive explanation of the pinhole camera model and its extensions in computer vision. Start with the ideal perspective projection geometry and derive the mapping from 3D world points to 2D image points using both Cartesian and homogeneous coordinates. Present the full camera matrix \(P = K [R \; t]\) and explain each component of the intrinsic matrix \(K\) (focal length, principal point, skew, pixel aspect ratio). Discuss the role of extrinsic parameters and the decomposition of \(P\). Then, cover real-world deviations: radial and tangential lens distortion models, and their parameterization (k1, k2, p1, p2). Describe the standard calibration procedure using multiple views of a checkerboard pattern, including corner detection, homography estimation, and nonlinear optimization. Finally, discuss limitations of the pinhole model (finite aperture blur, rolling shutter, chromatic aberration) and advanced models (rational polynomial, fisheye). Include mathematical formulations and practical implications for downstream tasks like 3D reconstruction and augmented reality.

criteria.description: Defines ideal perspective projection with infinitesimal aperture.
Derives \(x = f X/Z, y = f Y/Z\) geometrically.
States \(P = K [R | t]\) with correct dimensions.
Lists all five: \(\alpha_x, \alpha_y, s, c_x, c_y\).
Relates physical \(f\) to pixel units via sensor size.
Optical center offset; often near image center.
Non-zero in scanned film or misaligned sensors.
6 DOF rigid transformation from world to camera.
Polynomial model with \(k_1, k_2, k_3\); barrel/pincushion.
Bonus: lines at infinity for calibration.

rubric.grading_notes: Require correct projection equations and full K matrix for full marks. Award partial credit for good geometric intuition without full math. Deduct if intrinsic/extrinsic roles are swapped or distortion model direction is wrong. Bonus for mentioning modern tools (OpenCV calibrateCamera).
